title: The Verb 'To Have' (Έχω)
reading_greek:
CONJUGATION (Present)
Εγώ έχω (I have)
Εσύ έχεις (You have)
Αυτός έχει (He has)
Εμείς έχουμε (We have)
Εσείς έχετε (You have)
Αυτοί έχουν (They have)

EXAMPLES (Note the Accusative!)
1. Έχω ένα βιβλίο (I have a book).
2. Έχεις ένα αυτοκίνητο;
3. Ο Πέτρος έχει χρόνο (Peter has time).
4. Η Μαρία έχει δουλειά.
5. Έχουμε φίλους (We have friends).
6. Έχετε ερωτήσεις;
7. Τα παιδιά έχουν πείνα (The children are hungry - literally 'have hunger').
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: THE VERB 'TO HAVE'

1. OBLIGATORY ACCUSATIVE: When you 'have' something, that something is the OBJECT.
   - You cannot say 'Exo O Petros' (I have The Peter - Nominative).
   - You must say 'Exo TON Petro' (I have The Peter - Accusative).

2. PHYSICAL STATES: Greek uses 'Have' for hunger/thirst/cold.
   - 'Exo peina' ( I have hunger = I am hungry).
   - 'Exo dipsa' (I have thirst = I am thirsty).
audio_script:
Chapter 3! The Verb 'Exo' (To Have). 

This is the second most important verb after 'Eimai'. 
Memorize the endings: -o, -eis, -ei, -oume, -ete, -oun. 

Crucial Rule: The object of 'Exo' is ALWAYS in the Accusative Case. 
You don't 'have' a subject. You 'have' an object. 

Also, a fun tip: In English you 'are' hungry. In Greek, you 'have' hunger (Exo peina). 
Don't say 'Eimai peina' (I am hunger) - that means you are the abstract concept of starvation!

quiz_questions.question: How do you say 'I am hungry' in Greek?
quiz_questions.explanation: We use 'Have' for physical states like hunger/thirst.

quiz_questions.question: Grammatically, the object of 'Exo' (to have) is in which case?
quiz_questions.explanation: Because it is the direct object of the verb.

quiz_questions.question: Translate: 'The children represent hunger' (Make no sense? No, 'The children are hungry').
